TextContentOutputFormat Data Type

Enum that maps to the "text_content_output_format" HTTP header and query string parameter.

The serialization of textContentDTO objects an depend on three factors:

  • The text_content_output_format HTTP header or query string parameter.
  • The field definition's "rich text" setting (whether rich text is supported for the field).
  • The storage format of the data on the server.
Each of the text_content_output_format settings will do things differently. See comments of each one for details.

You can specify the text_content_output_format as an HTTP header or query string parameter. If both are specified, the query string parameter takes precedence.

Here's an example of specifying the text_content_output_format as a query string parameter: 

https://server/rest/orgs/201/incidents/54321?text_content_output_format=objects_convert

Values
value description
default textContentDTO objects are sent to the client as strings. The string will be in HTML format if the corresponding field (e.g. incident description, resolution_summary, etc.) is marked as a rich text field. If the corresponding field is not marked as rich text then the string will be in plain text format.

Example:

 "description": "Text incident description"
objects_convert textContentDTO objects are sent to the client as JSON objects. The "content" and "format" properties will be consistent with the corresponding field (e.g. incident description, resolution summary, etc.) definition. For example, if the field is marked as rich text, the "format" will be "html" and the "content" will be an HTML rendition of the string. Note that this may require the server to convert the string. If the data is stored in the database as plain text, but the field is a rich text field then the textContentDTO data will be converted from plain text to HTML.

Example:

 "description": {
  "format": "html",
  "content": "<div>Description</div>"
 }
objects_no_convert textContentDTO objects are sent to the client as JSON objects. The "content" and "format" properties will be consistent with the way the content is stored in the database. The returned content is not related to the field definition, so text content can be returned for rich text fields and vice-versa.

Example:

 "description": {
  "format": "html",
  "content": "<div>Description</div>"
 }
objects_convert_html textContentDTO objects are sent to the client as JSON objects. The "content" and "format" properties will be HTML, regardless of the rich text setting in the field definition and the data storage content. Note that this may require the server to do a plain text to HTML conversion.

Example:

 "description": {
  "format": "html",
  "content": "<div>Description</div>"
 }
objects_convert_text textContentDTO objects are sent to the client as JSON objects. The "content" and "format" properties will be HTML, regardless of the rich text setting in the field definition and the data storage format. Note that this may require the server to do an HTML to plain text conversion, which will cause formatting to be dropped.

Example:

 "description": {
  "format": "text",
  "content": "Description"
 }
always_text Always output the field as a simple string that is in text format.
